div.p: PADVERTIZING, available anywhere in WRITING documents though belonging conceptually with the PRODUCTION aspect, attends to the details surrounding the promotion and marketing of a text. For instance, you may want to discuss examples of interesting publicity or promotional stunts. This element has no mandatory or optional sub-elements or attributes.

div.codeblock: <PADVERTIZING>Jane Smith's Poems on Several Occasions was advertised in several newspapers from 17 September 1731.</PADVERTIZING>
<PADVERTIZING>To publicize Amelia Bundlekin's forthcoming book of poetry (1966), three of her friends dangled naked from Nelsonâ€™s Column.</PADVERTIZING>

div.p: Eighteenth-century prefaces that call themselves advertisements are not to be dealt with here. This tag is also not to be used for instances of advertising for other books when those ads are printed in the book under discussion.
Question: A bi-plane writes advertising in the sky in Mrs Dalloway. Do I tag it as advertising?
Answer: No, do not tag as advertising its appearance as subject-matter, but only about the promotional efforts directed to the book as a commodity.
